title: 109_s660
content: The "Lumbee Recognition Act" is the short title of this legislation. The preamble of the Act of June 7, 1956 is amended by making specific changes to the wording. The Lumbee Indians of North Carolina are descendants of coastal tribes, recognized by the state since 1885 and by Congress in 1956. The Lumbee Indians of North Carolina, descendants of coastal tribes, are recognized by the state since 1885 and by Congress in 1956. Congress now acknowledges that the Lumbee Tribe should receive full Federal recognition with all associated benefits, privileges, and immunities. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to remove the last sentence of the first section and replace section 2 with a new section on recognition. Federal recognition is granted to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, extending all laws and regulations of the United States applicable to Indian tribes to the Lumbee Tribe and its members. Any group of Indians in Robeson and adjoining counties, North Carolina, not enrolled in the Lumbee Tribe may petition for acknowledgment of tribal existence. Eligibility for services and benefits is outlined in the Act. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are eligible for services and benefits provided to Indians. Members residing in specific counties are considered to be on or near a reservation for service delivery purposes. The Secretary verifies needs and budget for the tribe. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, upon verification of their tribal roll, collaborates with the Secretaries of Interior and Health and Human Services to determine needs and budget for eligible services. This information is included in budget requests submitted by both Secretaries. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina collaborates with the Secretaries of Interior and Health and Human Services to determine needs and budget for eligible services. The tribal roll defines the service population of the Tribe, subject to verification by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary's verification for the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is limited to confirming compliance with membership criteria in the Tribe's constitution adopted on November 11, 2000, to be completed within 1 year of enactment. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina seeks to convey fee land to the United States for trust purposes in Robeson County, North Carolina. The Secretary of the Interior will treat the land as on-reservation trust acquisitions. Additionally, state jurisdiction is addressed in the following section. The State of North Carolina has jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on land owned by the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina. The Secretary of the Interior can accept transfers of land from the state to the United States. The Attorney General of the United States can approve the transfer of jurisdiction from the State of North Carolina to the United States as part of an agreement between the Lumbee Tribe and the state. The transfer will not take effect until 2 years after the agreement. This section does not impact the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out this Act.
